0.user_question: John drives for 3 hours at a speed of 60 mph and then turns around because he realizes he forgot something very important at home.  He tries to get home in 4 hours but spends the first 2 hours in standstill traffic.  He spends the next half-hour driving at a speed of 30mph, before being able to drive the remaining time of the 4 hours going at 80 mph.  How far is he from home at the end of those 4 hours?

ost_step.1: John initially travelled for 3 hours at 60 mph which means that distance covered was 3*60=<<3*60=180>>180 miles away from his starting point (home).
ost_step.2: For the return journey, out initial two hour move showed no progress due to heavy traffic; so still remains 180 miles away during these times.
ost_step.3: Next one hour (half past) shows movement towards home covering another 30 * 1 = <<30*1=30>>30 miles reducing this gap by 30 miles making it now 180 – 30 = <<180-30=150>>150 miles apart.

First off, we need to calculate the distance covered when John was driving away from home at 60 mph. We know it took him 3 hours to reach a certain location while traveling at that constant speed. At this stage, John would be 180 miles away from his starting position near home.

However, as soon as he turned around, nothing changes about this calculation – whether he moved faster later didn’t matter here!

direct_answer.text: Firstly, let’s calculate the initial distance covered while traveling towards somewhere other than home which was unplanned due to forgetting essential items back home. Here it states ‘he drives for 3 hrs @ 60mph,’ so using formula Distance=Speed*Time here our calculated value comes as 3hrs*60(miles/hr)=180 miles away from Home. Thus, Initial displacement becomes '+180 miles'. Second phase involves getting caught up in standstill traffic lasting for the entirety of two hours hence effectively no movement takes place i.e., No change in Displacement or Remaining Mileage. Third stage indicates us having driven along roads running parallel until reaching cruising speeds allowing motion once again making use of same equation namely : Speed× Time . Consequently ,remaining milage can only become negative if Travel Rate exceeds Required Driving rate otherwise stays constant till required Destination reaches completion & therefore taking effect upon arrival without delay also noted since ;”He tried trying hard enough…”. Last part informs us exactly amount of mileages achieved pertaining specifically toward desired destination arriving precisely within stipulated period – four hours

Answer : \boxed{21}.

direct_answer.text:
Let's break down John's journey into segments and calculate the distances using the formula Distance = Speed × Time.

**Outbound Journey:**  
John drove for 3 hours at 60 mph.  
Distance traveled = Speed × Time  
Distance Outbound = 60 mph × 3 hrs = 180 miles

Due to forgetfulness about bringing something back home, John turned around immediately upon reaching this point. This means he covers another 180 miles while coming back toward his starting position. Thus, until this reversal moment, the net displacement was zero since returning him to the same spot as when leaving would cancel it all out. However, we need only consider additional travel post turnaround which makes us subtract one instance of such return trip leading up to stopping due to stationary traffic conditions—a deduction equalling twice the initial departure value reflective of both legs pre-halting period minus double itself summing once initially driven towards destination plus subsequent instantaneous reverse course prior encounter with gridlock thus implying removal effectuated via subtraction yields resultant spatial discrepancy henceforward emergent en route reinstatement amid
